question: Which of the following is true about celiac disease?

answers.option: Intestinal infection by anaerobes is implicated in its pathogenesis
Lamina propria of the small intestine is filled with foamy macrophages
Removal of lactose-containing products from diet improves symptoms
Patients have to avoid gluten containing diet throughout the life

question: Which of the following is the most common complication of peptic ulcers?
In which of the following diseases is the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) defective?
Which of the following diseases has impaired gastrointestinal motility?
Which of the following is not associated with celiac disease?
What does the presence of hepatitis B surface antibodies in routine blood tests indicate?

answers.option: Past infection and vaccination to hepatitis B
No successful recovery from the infection

question: Which of the following causes acute pancreatitis?
Which of the following causes cancer in peptic ulcers?
Which of the following is true for the morphology of Barrett's esophagus?

answers.option: One type of mucosa with no alternates

question: Which of the following is correct about hernias?

answers.option: Femoral hernia protrude above inguinal ligament
Indirect inguinal hernias are medial to inferior epigastric vessels
Direct inguinal hernia is not covered by external spermatic fascia
Diaphragmatic hernia in infants is most commonly due to hiatal hernia
Epigastric hernia is present between xiphisternum and umbilicus

question: Which of the following causes most of the cases of peptic ulcer disease?
Which of the following cancers is associated with helicobacter pylori?
What is the most common cause of chronic gastritis?
People with Barrett's esophagus have an increased risk of developing which of the following?

answers.option: Squamous cell carcinoma of the esophagus

question: Which of the following is not true about the features of von Gierke's disease?

A 65-year-old male came with complaints of abdominal distension and disorientation. He was a known case of liver cirrhosis. He lost follow-up with his physician and ended up in an emergency room. His previous liver biopsy showed nodular liver and portal hypertension. The nodular liver appearance in cirrhosis is due to which of the following?

A 50-year-old man presents to the emergency room with severe abdominal pain referred to the upper back and left shoulder along with nausea and vomiting. Pain is not relieved by nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs). He has a long history of alcohol abuse. The physician is suspecting acute pancreatitis. Which of the following findings is most likely to be present in the patient?
Reflux from which of the following parts of the gastrointestinal tract plays a role in the feedback control of the ileocecal valve?

A 50-year-old man complains of persistent nausea for 5 years with occasional bouts of vomiting. On examination, no abnormal findings are seen. His upper gastrointestinal (GI) endoscopy shows a small area of gastric fundal mucosa with loss of frugal folds. Microscopy of biopsy reveals well-differentiated adenocarcinoma. An upper GI endoscopy performed 5 years previously showed a pattern of gastritis and microscopically there was chronic inflammation. Which of the following is the most likely risk factor for his neoplasm?
What is the average peak age for the onset of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD)?

A 34-year-old man presents with a 5-month history of weakness and fatigue. There is no history of any drug or alcohol abuse. His complete blood count (CBC) shows Hb = 7.2 g/dL with an MCV = 115 fL, low platelet and hypersegmented neutrophils. This patient must be investigated for which of the following things?

A 25-year-old male consulted a physician for his deranged liver function test parameters showing total bilirubin = 4 mg/dL, indirect bilirubin = 3.1 mg/dL (normal = 0.2-0.7 mg/dL), SGPT and alkaline phosphatase normal, and complete blood count (CBC) report also normal. There is a history of recurrent jaundice since childhood, especially associated with fasting. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Which of the following terms is defined as the abnormal accumulation of fat in the liver cells?
Which of the following arteries is most likely to bleed in the duodenal ulcer?
Which of the following is caused by alcoholic hematemesis?
What type of gastritis presents with increased intraepithelial neutrophils and lymphoid aggregations deep into gastric tissue?
A person presents with vomiting, nausea, upper abdominal discomfort, but no hematemesis. What is the most likely cause?

A 40-year-old male is admitted to the hospital with the complaint of fever, nausea, vomiting, dark yellow color of eyes, and urine. Lab findings show that he is hepatitis C positive. Which of the following statements is true regarding this case?

answers.option: Person-to-person contact is important in transmission
It is safe for him to donate blood to others
The disease is transmitted through contaminated blood
There is complete recovery after infection

question: Which of the following is the most common means of spread of hepatitis C in western countries?
Gastric carcinoma is associated with which one of the following factors?

A slim, 40-year-old mother of 5 children presents to the clinic with a subcutaneous swelling in the groin. Upon examination, it is found that she has a hernia and should opt for surgical repair. Which of the following is the most likely hernia in this patient?

A patient presents to the clinic with complaints of dark urine and clay-colored stools. Upon physical examination, scleral icterus and yellowing of the skin are observed. Which of the following would most likely be the cause of the given symptoms?
Which of the following may precipitate the clinical features in celiac disease?

A 38-year-old male presents to the emergency room with complaints of upper abdominal discomfort. He has yellowish discoloration of sclera. His liver function test (LFT) shows total bilirubin = 18 mg/dL, direct bilirubin = 16.2 mg/dL (normal = 0.1-0.3 mg/dL), indirect bilirubin = 1.8 mg/dL (normal = 0.2-0.7 mg/dL), SGPT = 100 units/L (normal = < 30 units/L), and alkaline phosphatase = 800 units/L (normal = 30-115 units/L). What will be the most probable cause of his deranged LFT?
Which of the following conditions is responsible for pathologically high levels of unconjugated bilirubin in a newborn's blood?
Which of the following is the most common cause of gastric ulcer in antrum?

A 38-year-old male, senior administrative officer in a private firm, presents to the outpatient clinic with difficulty in swallowing (dysphagia) for solid food. The problem started with the feeling of a lump in the throat progressing to dysphagia with solid food. He has lost a significant amount of weight over the past few months which, according to him, is due to his reduced appetite. On examination, the conjunctiva is pale with spoon-shaped nails. He is a chain-smoker and drinks occasionally. He has a past history of heartburn and black stools. The significant lab findings are: Hb = 8.0 mg/dL, mean cell hemoglobin = 18.4 pg/cell, mean corpuscular volume (MCV) = 70 fL. What is the most likely cause of the above-described findings?
Which of the following is seen in celiac disease?
Which of the following is a common complication of celiac disease?
Which of the following is the most common site for gastric ulcer?
What is the presence of small and large fatty acid droplets called?
Which enzyme in Helicobacter pylori creates an alkaline environment?
Which of the following causes sinusoidal obstruction?
Which of the following is not associated with portal hypertension?
Viruses in hepatitis have different modes of transmission. Which of the following transmits through the orofecal route?

A 52-year-old woman has been experiencing malaise that has worsened during the past year. On physical examination, mild scleral icterus is identified. There is no ascites or splenomegaly. The serologic findings are positive for IgG, anti-HCV, and HCV RNA; negative for anti-HAV, hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg), ANA, and anti-mitochondrial antibody. The serum AST (aspartate aminotransferase) and ALT (alanine transaminase) levels are raised. Her condition remains stable for months. Which of the following morphological findings is most likely to be present in this patient's liver?

A 50-year-old woman has a long-standing history of rheumatoid arthritis for which she is taking nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs). Her gastroscopy reveals superficial mucosal defects with loss of epithelium. Which of the following conditions is the woman most likely to be suffering from?
In diabetes mellitus, which of the following organs is most affected?
Hyperlipidemia is most likely to be found in which of the following conditions?
Which disease and its causative enzyme deficiency is incorrectly paired?
Which of the following diseases is caused by a pathogen that invades the small intestine?
What is the structure of the Hepatitis C virus?
Which of the following is a feature of ulcerative colitis?
Travellers are most commonly affected by what hepatitis?
Mutations in which of the gene can be a possible cause of peptic ulcer disease?
Which of the following is the most appropriate for the route of transmission of hepatitis C?
Which of the following sites is most likely to have the gallstone lodged within?
Which of the following is a major cause of celiac disease?
Apart from peptic ulcer, the stomach may be involved in which of the following diseases?
The body of the patient is found to produce endomysial antibodies with the intestinal biopsy showing the presence of flattened villi. Which of the following diseases is this hinting towards?

A 1-month-old baby is brought to the emergency room with a distended lower abdomen. According to the parents, he has passed stool since birth. On examination, there is a mass in the left iliac region which moves on palpation. The abdomen is otherwise soft, with gut sounds audible. An ultrasound scan reveals retained feces in the pelvic colon. Which of the following is the most likely reason for his condition?

answers.option: Absence of myenteric plexus in pelvic colon
Absence of submucosal plexus in the pelvis colon
Presence of stricture in ileocecal valve
Absence of mucus glands in colon

question: A 58-year-old obese female came to the gastroenterologist for the complaint of severe indigestion and mild yellowish discoloration of the sclera. She was also experiencing nausea and vomiting on and off for the past six months. Laboratory results confirmed RNA virus causing chronic hepatitis and on abdominal X-ray, a severe fatty liver was observed. What is the most likely cause of this condition?
Which of the following antibodies are produced in celiac disease?
Which of the following is not a cause of coronary artery disease?
What can be used to test for non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH)?
The levels of which of the following enzymes predominantly increase during liver failure?

A young girl was brought to the emergency room due to severe pain in the right lower quadrant. The patient gives a history of pain that started from the epigastrium. Which of the following features is characteristic of the organ involved?

answers.option: Numerous crypts in the lamina propria
Abundance of lymphoid tissue in submucosa

question: Which of the following is true regarding gastroesophageal reflux disease?

answers.option: Contents from the stomach move up into the esophagus
The esophagus shows a bird beak sign on X-ray
Contents from the esophagus move down into the stomach

question: A 15-year-old boy presents with a long-standing history of abdominal pain and weight loss of 10 kg over the past year. Physical examination reveals peripheral edema and ascites. Laboratory studies show decreased serum albumin, while his liver function test is normal. On gross examination, there is an irregular enlargement of gastric rugae in the body and fundus, and on microscopic examination, there is hyperplasia of foveolar mucous cells. Which of the following is he most likely to be suffering from?
In which of the following can the hemorrhoids develop from the increased pressure in the lower extremities?
A person got into an accident and presents with pain in his lower anterior abdomen. Which of the following nerves is most likely to be involved in this?
Which enzyme is deficient in von Gierke disease?

A 10-year-old boy had fever, nausea, and pain on the right side of the abdomen for the past 4 days and today he developed a yellowish tinge in his eyes. He has been eating snacks from a roadside vendor. He is brought to the outpatient department for treatment. His test results are still awaited. What is the route of transmission of his suspected disease?

A 45-year-old man has had vague abdominal pain for the past 3 years. This pain is unrelieved by antacid medications. He has no difficulty in swallowing and no heartburn following meals. On physical examination, there are no abnormal findings. Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy reveals antral mucosal erythema but no ulcerations or masses. Biopsies are taken and, microscopically, there is a chronic, non-specific gastritis. Which of the following conditions is likely present in this man?

A 38-year-old man has had upper abdominal pain for 3 months. For the past week, he has had nausea. On physical examination, a stool sample is positive for occult blood. Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy reveals no esophageal lesions, but there is a solitary 2 cm diameter shallow, sharply demarcated ulceration of the stomach. Which of the following is most characteristic of this lesion?

A 72-year-old man takes large quantities of non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) because of chronic degenerative arthritis of the hips and knees. Over the past 2 weeks, he has had epigastric pain with nausea and vomiting and an episode of hematemesis. On physical examination, there are no remarkable findings. A gastric biopsy specimen is most likely to show which of the following lesions?

A 49-year-old woman presents with a history of yellow discoloration of her eyes, abdominal pain, weight loss, and low-grade fever. On examination, her liver is found to be palpable 2 cm below the right costal margin. Laboratory analysis reveals a decreased serum albumin, and an elevated serum aspartate aminotransferase (AST) and alanine aminotransferase (ALT). Moderate leukocytosis is also seen. Her liver biopsy shows steatosis and hydropic swelling, focal necrosis, and cytoplasmic hyaline inclusions within the hepatocytes (Mallory bodies). What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 60-year-old man has a history of abdominal swelling. Every day, he smokes two packets of cigarettes, drinks five cups of coffee, and consumes two packs of beer. On examination, his liver is palpable 2 cm below the right costal margin. Laboratory analysis reveals a decreased serum albumin, and an elevated serum aspartate aminotransferase (AST) and alanine aminotransferase (ALT). Liver biopsy shows steatosis and hydropic swelling. If this patient becomes abstinent, his liver would most likely undergo which of the following processes?
Pancreatitis refers to inflammation of the pancreas and can be of two types, acute and chronic. Which of the following statements is correct regarding pancreatitis?

answers.option: Chronic pancreatitis is characterised by reversible damage to the pancreas
Alcohol plays no significant role in its etiology
Primary acinar cell injury leads to the release of digestive enymes
Laboratory findings are unhelpful in establishing a diagnosis

question: A 35-year-old female presents to the emergency room with an acute abdomen. She was scheduled to undergo surgery for the removal of her gall bladder due to gallstones in a week but suddenly developed acute abdominal pain. The pain was constant, intense, and radiated to her upper back. She also has nausea and vomiting. Laboratory investigations show elevated levels of amylase and lipase. Radiological investigations suggest obstruction of the pancreatic duct. Which of the following statements is correct regarding the patient's condition?

answers.option: Results in irreversible damage to pancreatic parenchyma
Can be complicated by disseminated intravascular coagulation
Advisable to drink lots of water to flush out any obstruction
Can be treated with analgesics and sent home

question: One week after a trip, a 31-year-old woman had increasingly severe diarrhea. Gross examination of the stools showed mucus and streaks of blood. The diarrheal illness subsided within a couple of weeks, but now the patient has become febrile and has pain in the right upper quadrant of his abdomen. An abdominal ultrasound scan shows a 10 cm, irregular, partly cystic mass in the right upper lobe. Which of the following infectious organisms is most likely to produce these findings?
Which of the following markers indicate immunity to hepatitis infection?
Against which types of hepatitis viruses have vaccines been developed?

A 20-year-old woman presents with a 2-year history of difficulty swallowing and increasing fatigue. A complete blood count (CBC) reveals an iron deficiency anemia. Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy reveals an annular narrowing in the upper third of the esophagus. A mucosal biopsy shows no evidence of inflammation or neoplasia. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 35-year-old man complains of difficulty swallowing and a tendency to regurgitate his food. Endoscopy does not reveal any esophageal or gastric abnormalities. Manometric studies of the esophagus show a complete absence of peristalsis, failure of the lower esophageal sphincter to relax open upon swallowing, and increased intraesophageal pressure. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 45-year-old woman presents with general discomfort and increasing tightness in the skin of her face. She reports intermittent pain in the tips of her fingers when exposed to the cold. Physical examination shows "stone facies" and edema of the fingers and hands. Serologic tests for antinuclear and anti-Scl-70 antibodies are both positive. Which of the following gastrointestinal manifestations is expected in this patient?

answers.option: Squamous cell carcinoma of the esophagus

question: Which of the following serves as a reservoir for Vibrio cholerae?
AIDS-associated peliosis in the liver leads to which pathogen being found in perisinusoidal space?
A patient is diagnosed with ankylosing spondylitis. Which gastrointestinal manifestation should be suspected?
Which is the best way to determine staging and diagnosis of gastric carcinoma?
What is the screening diagnostic test for hepatitis C infection?
What is the best test for determining residual H. Pylori infection?

A patient comes to the clinic with a complaint of pain in the epigastric region for past 2-3 months. Pain is apparent 2-3 hours after taking a meal. A peptic ulcer is suspected. Which is the most common area for a ulcer to be found in?
Which of the following is the most common complication of peptic ulcer?
A person presents to the clinic with intermittent diarrhea and is diagnosed as a case of malabsorption. Which of the following is the most frequent manifestation in malabsorption?

A person presents to the emergency department with chronic diarrhea and abdominal pain for months. Findings show aphthous ulcers, deep linear fissures occupying the ascending and transverse colon but sparing the rectum and descending colon with skipped areas with excess fat creeping over mucosa. Cryptitis is also seen in lamina propria along with non-caseating granulomas. Which is the most probable diagnosis?
Chronic pancreatitis presents with malabsorption. Which of the following phases of nutrient digestion and absorption is affected in chronic pancreatitis?

A lady with a case of malabsorption presents with swelling in the midline of the neck and increased levels of thyroid-stimulating hormone. She has been diagnosed with megaloblastic anemia with increased MCV. Antibodies against which of the following could be a reason for her anemia?
A clinic has a case of malabsorption and megaloblastic anemia. Antibodies against which component could be a cause of this anemia?
Which of the following is due to the failure of the return of the physiological herniation of the gut in the yolk sac back into the abdominal cavity?
Which enzyme deficiency occurs in Cori's disease?
Lysosomal storage disease occurs due to the buildup of complex carbohydrates or lipids primarily due to which of the following?
Which finding will support a diagnosis of Crohn's rather than ulcerative colitis?
What is the time during which someone is infected by a pathogen and the person carries the disease without the onset of symptoms called?
A newborn's failure to pass meconium within the first 24 hours after birth may indicate which of the following?
What is the cause of nonspecific bacterial sialadenitis, frequently involving submandibular glands?

A 40-year-old woman has had increasing abdominal girth for a month, and pain for the past few days. On physical examination, there is hepatomegaly and caput medusae. Laboratory studies show hemoglobin 20.5 g/dL, hematocrit 61.7%, platelet count 411,000/mm3, aspartate transaminase (AST) 333 U/L, and alanine transaminase (ALT) 358 U/L. What is ultrasonography of her abdomen most likely to show?
Barrett esophagus is a serious, long-term complication of chronic gastroesophageal reflux. Which of the following conditions is diagnostic for Barrett esophagus?
Which of the following is true regarding hepatitis C virus (HCV) infection?

answers.option: Anti-HCV antibody is protective against subsequent infections
Viral RNA disappears when anti-HCV appears in the blood
Episodic elevations of serum aminotransferase levels
Being an RNA virus, vertical transmission is not possible
Increased levels of anti-HCV antibodies confer effective immunity

question: Which of the following conditions is true regarding the presence of antibodies against hepatitis B surface antigen in blood?

answers.option: Indicates a complete recovery or immunity
It is detectable after HBsAg disappears
Indicates immunity after inoculation with HBV vaccine
Helps to distinguish acute from chronic infection

question: A 45-year-old man with long-standing gastroesophageal reflux undergoes upper gastrointestinal endoscopy that reveals patchy areas of epithelium resembling gastric mucosa extending 5 cm proximal to the esophagogastric junction. Biopsies are obtained. The pathological report describes "Barrett esophagus". Which of the following processes does this finding represent?
What is the most common tumor of the parotid gland?
The biopsy specimen taken from the stomach shows a superficial mucosal defect and mucosal neutrophilic infiltrate. Which term best describes the features?
Which one of the following is unlikely to be the morphological feature of Helicobacter pylori gastritis?

answers.option: Increased parietal cell mass and acid secretion

question: Which one of the following is a reversible hepatic response to injury?

A 53-year-old male came to the emergency department due to marked hematemesis for the last three hours. On examination, he had a distended abdomen and fluid wave. What is the patient likely suffering from?

A 40-year-old male patient visits the outpatient department with complaints of epigastric pain. The pain is relieved by meals and antacids. Gastric analysis shows increased basal and active acid secretion. Which of the following causes gastric hypersecretion?
What is the most common cause of pancreatitis?
Which of the following conditions is predominant unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia most likely associated with?
Which of the following is the mode of inheritance of Dubin-Johnson syndrome?
Which of the following is the most common cause of chronic gastritis and cancer?

A 54-year-old alcoholic male presents with a sudden onset of severe, constant, epigastric pain that radiates to his midback. Further evaluation finds fever, steatorrhea, and discoloration around his flank and umbilicus, Lab investigation reveals elevated serum amylase and lipase levels. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 55-year-old man gives a 6-month history of recurrent epigastric pain, progressive weight loss, and foul-smelling diarrhea. He is anemic while abdominal pain is now almost constant and intractable. An X-ray film of the abdomen reveals multiple areas of calcification in the mid-abdomen. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 23-year-old primigravida gives birth at term. Ultrasound examination before delivery showed polyhydramnios. It is noted that the infant vomits all feedings, then develops a fever and difficulty with respiration within 2 days. The radiograph shows both lungs and the heart are of normal size, but there are no pulmonary infiltrates or stomach bubbles. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Which one of the following statements best describes the microscopic findings in autoimmune pancreatitis?

answers.option: Extensive hemorrhage within the substance of the gland with increased neutrophils
Necrosis of acinar and ductal tissues and necrosis of islets of Langerhans
Duct-centric mixed inflammatory cell infiltrate, venulitis, and increased plasma cells
Dilated ducts with eosinophilic ductal concretions with increased neutrophils
Extensive fibrosis and atrophy have left only residual islets and ducts with a sprinkling of chronic exudate

question: Apart from history, what is the basic morphological feature that supports chronic pancreatitis instead of acute pancreatitis?

answers.option: Necrosis of acinar and ductal tissue

question: Which of the following is the least likely to be visualized in a microscope when examining a gastric biopsy from a patient with acute gastritis?
Which of the following presents with symptoms of obstruction as well as compromised blood supply?
No single test for H.pylori is considered the gold standard, but which of the following tests is likely to confirm the diagnosis accurately?

answers.option: Bacterial DNA detection by PCR in gastric biopsy
Rapid urease test in gastric biopsy
Urea breath test (based on generation of NH3 by bacterial urease)
Serologic test for antibodies to bacteria

question: A middle-aged woman without significant past medical history presents with acute onset of fatigue and jaundice. Blood tests show markedly elevated aspartate aminotransferase, alanine aminotransferase, and high titer antinuclear antibody. Serologies for smooth muscle antibody and anti-mitochondrial antibody are both positive. What is the most probable diagnosis?
Which of the following levels does the bilirubin usually reach to cause jaundice?
Which of the following treatments are offered first for infants diagnosed with biliary atresia?

A 70-year-old male presents with abdominal pain and severe weight loss in two months. On endoscopy, a submucosal mass in the gastric region is noted and a biopsy shows diffuse sheets of small cells with vacuolated cytoplasm and eccentrically placed nuclei. Which of the following statements is true for the condition mentioned above?

answers.option: The diffuse infiltrative pattern carcinomas are mostly composed of signet ring cells
The most commonly affected gene is CDKN2A
There is presence of E-cadherin in these cells
The intestinal type carcinomas mostly penetrate the gastric wall
The most powerful prognostic indicator is tumor depth of invasion only in gastric cancers

question: A 42-year-old female with a history of dyspepsia for a long time and who has been on proton pump inhibitors undergoes an endoscopy which showed multiple polyps in the gastric fundus. Which of the following statements is true for the above condition?

answers.option: These polyps are always associated nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain
Alteration of APC beta-catenin pathway are seen in both sporadic and syndromic fundic gland polyps
These polyps are highly associated with H. pylori infections
The majority of hyperplastic polyps are 3 cm in size
These polyps are not associated with the use of proton pump inhibitors

question: Which of the following is not a contributor to circulatory disorders of the liver?

The portal vein is the blood vessel that brings blood to the liver from the intestines. Portal vein thrombosis is the blockage or narrowing of the portal vein by a blood clot. Which of the following symptoms do most people with portal vein thrombosis have?
Which of the following is the best method for diagnosis of intestinal parasites?

answers.option: Microscopy of stool in saline and iodine

question: Any treatment that can lower water activity such as sun drying can reduce or eliminate the growth of microorganisms. Humectants such as sugar, salt, and alcohol can bind water to make it unavailable as a solvent. Which of the following best defines this process of food preservation?
Which of the following investigations is the gold standard for the diagnosis of Helicobacter pylori (H. pylori) infection?

answers.option: Serum levels of antibodies specific for H. pylori
Stool culture for H. pylori antigen
Endoscopy with tissue biopsy and culture

question: Which of the following may be a complication of H. pylori infection?
What is the screening test for HCV?
A 20-year-old male, after 3 weeks of having dinner at a roadside stall, presents with diarrhea and jaundice. Which of the following is the most likely used for the diagnosis?
What is the most common route of the spread of the Hepatitis C Virus (HCV)?
Pruritus and an onion ring appearance morphology are characteristic of which of the following conditions?
A person has a ground glass appearance on morphology and is unsure if the hepatitis B vaccine was administered. Which of the following would indicate that an infection is not present?

A 45-year-old male presents with a year-long history of heartburn and regurgitation, worsened by lying down, and recent difficulty swallowing solid foods. He reports temporary relief with antacids. An upper GI endoscopy reveals red, irregular, salmon-colored mucosa extending from the gastroesophageal junction into the lower esophagus. Biopsy confirms the presence of intestinal metaplasia with goblet cells replacing the normal squamous epithelium. The patient has a history of occasional alcohol use and smoking but is otherwise healthy. Which of the following best explains the cellular changes observed in the biopsy of the patient’s esophagus?

answers.option: Chronic irritation leading to squamous metaplasia
Chronic acid exposure resulting in intestinal metaplasia
Conversion of columnar epithelium to squamous epithelium
Increased proliferation of esophageal squamous cells

question: A 45-year-old male presents with a year-long history of heartburn and regurgitation, worsened by lying down, and recent difficulty swallowing solid foods. He reports temporary relief with antacids but recurrent symptoms. An upper GI endoscopy reveals red, irregular, salmon-colored mucosa extending from the gastroesophageal junction into the lower esophagus. Biopsy confirms the presence of intestinal metaplasia with goblet cells replacing the normal squamous epithelium. The patient has a history of occasional alcohol use and smoking but is otherwise healthy. Which of the following best explains how gastric acid contributes to this patient’s symptoms and condition?

answers.option: Gastric acid aids in neutralizing bile salts
Gastric acid secretion is decreased in GERD
Gastric acid reflux into the esophagus damages the mucosa
Gastric acid helps activate pepsinogen in the esophagus

question: No single test for H. Pylori is considered the gold standard. Which of the following tests is most likely to confirm the diagnosis accurately?

answers.option: Serologic test for antibodies to bacteria
Bacterial DNA detection by PCR using gastric biopsy
Urea breath test (based on generation of NH3 by bacterial urease)
Rapid urease test using gastric biopsy

question: A 1-week-old male neonate is brought to the emergency department by his parents. The baby appears sluggish and breathing rapidly. The mother explains that her baby has been fussy for the last several days and is not feeding well. Today, he has been vomiting a lot and is very sleepy. The pregnancy was uneventful, and the baby was delivered by normal vaginal birth. Blood studies reveal a normal anion gap. Which of the following pathological processes is most likely responsible for these symptoms?

answers.option: Long-chain fatty acids accumulation due to carnitine deficiency
Phenylketonuria due to phenylalanine hydroxylase deficiency
Hyperammonemia due to an error of the urea cycle

question: A 16-year-old young male came to the outpatient department with complaints of right upper abdominal pain, nausea, and dark urine for the past week. He was a smoker but recently developed a distaste for cigarettes. He recently returned from his native town in interior Sindh. His cousin who accompanied him also had similar complaints. What is the most likely cause of hepatitis in this case?
What is the most common cause of Traveler’s diarrhea?
What is the most common cause of chronic pancreatitis in adults?

A 45-year-old male with a 15-year history of heavy alcohol consumption (an average of 8-10 drinks daily) presents to the clinic with weakness, weight loss, and abdominal pain. A liver ultrasound shows fatty liver changes and the patient is diagnosed with alcoholic liver disease. The physician explains that the development of alcoholic liver disease involves several mechanisms, including metabolic, inflammatory, and oxidative processes. Which of the following mechanisms is most directly involved in the early stages of alcoholic liver disease pathogenesis?

answers.option: Increased oxidative stress leading to lipid peroxidation
Activation of stellate cells causing fibrosis
Deposition of amyloid proteins in hepatocytes
Direct hepatocyte damage by acetaldehyde, a toxic alcohol metabolite

question: A 40-year-old male presents to the emergency department with worsening right upper quadrant pain, high fever, and shortness of breath. He was diagnosed with an amoebic liver abscess two weeks ago and started on metronidazole. Despite treatment, his symptoms have worsened. On physical examination, he has decreased breath sounds on the right side and tenderness in the right upper quadrant. A chest X-ray shows an elevated right hemidiaphragm with pleural effusion. Laboratory tests reveal leukocytosis and mildly raised liver enzymes. Which of the following is the most likely cause of these findings in this patient?

answers.option: Septicemia secondary to acute kidney injury
Portal vein thrombosis leading to bowel ischemia
Rupture into the pleural cavity causing a pleural effusion
Chronic granulomatous inflammation of the liver

question: Which of the following is the most likely complication of untreated nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH)?
Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism of sinusoidal obstruction syndrome?

answers.option: Viral hepatitis causing damage to hepatic sinusoids
Bacterial infection leading to liver abscess formation
Damage to endothelial cells lining the hepatic sinusoids by chemotherapy
Hepatocyte necrosis due to ischemic injury

question: Which of the following is the most likely cause of portal hypertension?

answers.option: Hepatic cirrhosis secondary to alcohol use

question: Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of duodenal perforation?
What is the most common cause of cholestatic syndrome in adults?

A 65-year-old male with a history of cirrhosis secondary to chronic hepatitis C presents to the emergency department with hematemesis, confusion, lethargy, and inappropriate behavior. His family reports that he has been increasingly disoriented over the past two days. On examination, he has jaundice, ascites, and asterixis (flapping tremor). Laboratory tests reveal elevated ammonia levels. Which of the following is the most likely precipitating factor for this patient’s condition?
